title: Kamala Harris will become the first woman to give a West Point commencement speech
description: The vice president will make history this weekend when she delivers remarks to the 2023 graduating class at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, which was established over two centuries ago.

title: Yellen sets new deadline for Congress to raise the debt ceiling: June 5
description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says unless lawmakers raise the debt ceiling by June 5, the government won't have enough money to pay all of its bills.

title: A judge halts South Carolina's new abortion law pending state Supreme Court review
description: A judge put South Carolina's new law banning most abortions around six weeks of pregnancy on hold until the state Supreme Court can review the measure.

title: Three-term Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton faces calls for impeachment
description: A Texas House committee has recommended impeaching Republican Attorney General Ken Paxton who it says has abused his office to help a campaign donor, alleging bribery, obstruction of justice and more.

title: We asked, you answered: How do you feel about the end of the COVID-19 'emergency'
description: With the WHO and CDC lifting the COVID-19 pandemic "emergency," we asked readers what was on their minds at this inflection point. Their reflections run the gamut, and also reveal some clear themes.

title: She's trying to archive Black Twitter. It's a delicate and imperfect task
description: Black Twitter has been a force since the platform started. Now, one woman is seeking to archive it, as Twitter's future appears uncertain.

title: Ophelia Dahl on her Radcliffe Prize and lessons learned from Paul Farmer and her youth
description: She was a co-founder of Partners in Health with Dr. Paul Farmer. Dahl reflects on her philosophy and goals — and what she learned from Farmer, who died last year.

title: A boy, 11, called police in Mississippi. A cop shot him
description: Nakala Murry says her son doesn't understand what happened to him. "His words to me were: 'Why did he shoot me? What did I do?' "

title: White House and Capitol Hill negotiators reach some agreements to avoid default
description: The Treasury estimates the country could default on its loans as early as June 1. But negotiators are still hashing out key provisions including work requirements and permitting reform.

title: Can multivitamins improve memory? A new study shows 'intriguing' results
description: A team of researchers tracked thousands of people who took a daily multivitamin for three years. At the end of the first year they preformed slightly better on memory tests than people on a placebo.

title: DEA revokes a major drug distributor's license over opioid crisis failures
description: The U.S. agency stripped Morris & Dickson Co. of its license to sell highly addictive painkillers after determining it failed to flag thousands of suspicious orders at the height of the opioid crisis.

title: 40 years ago, NPR had to apologize for airing 'Return of the Jedi' spoilers
description: Back in 1983, All Things Considered host Susan Stamberg asked a young moviegoer to give us a "sneak preview" of Return of the Jedi. The flood of complaints from listeners led to an on-air apology.

title: One dead, 15 wounded in a Russian strike on a Ukrainian medical clinic
description: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenksyy called the attack on a Dnipro medical clinic a "crime against humanity." Video of the scene showed smoke pouring out of a badly damaged building.

title: South Korea detains a passenger after a door opens on Asiana flight in mid-air
description: No one was injured as some people aboard the Asiana Airlines Airbus A321 aircraft tried to stop the person from opening the door but it was eventually opened partially, the government said.

title: Vietnam's human rights record is being scrutinized ahead of $15 billion climate deal
description: Environmental and human rights groups say Vietnam's crackdown on civil society will undermine an international climate program that's also aimed at boosting the country's economic development.

title: Republican candidates hope to win in Iowa as they look to topple Trump in 2024
description: Republicans are showing up in Iowa early and often, trying to stand out against the big personality that former President Donald Trump brings to the GOP primary.

title: Yes, Puerto Rican licenses are valid in the U.S., Hertz reminds its employees
description: A Puerto Rican man was denied a car rental at a Hertz location at the New Orleans airport where employees apparently believed his driver's license was from outside the U.S. Hertz has since apologized.

title: Here are 19 books our critics are excited for this summer
description: We asked some of our regular book critics what soon-to-be-published titles they are most looking forward to reading this summer. Here's what they said.

title: Test yourself against NPR's weekly news quiz. For example: Who is this guy?
description: Debt ceiling. DeSantis. Dynamic duo. A lot happened this week. Were you paying attention?

title: 20 of the world's richest economies, including the U.S., are fueling forced labor
description: A report released by human rights organization Walk Free found that the number of people living in modern slavery, including forced marriage and human trafficking, has grown to 50 million since 2018.

title: Portugal police end latest search for clues of missing British girl
description: Authorities gave no details about the search for clues of the missing Madeleine McCann. Portugal said some material had been collected and will be given to German authorities to examine.

title: Indiana reprimands doctor who spoke publicly about providing 10-year-old's abortion
description: Caitlin Bernard, an Indiana OBGYN, has been under scrutiny from her state's Republican attorney general since speaking out about the impact of the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade.

title: Max streaming service says it will restore writer and director credits after outcry
description: Warner Bros. Discovery's new streaming platform lopped off the individual credits for writers, directors and producers. After TV and film unions condemned the move, the streaming giant apologized.
